title: Hugh McCabe
text:
Hugh McCabe (1955 – 28 May 2017) was a <a href="Gaelic%20football">Gaelic football</a> <a href="Manager%20%28Gaelic%20games%29">manager</a> and player whose <a href="National%20Football%20League%20%28Ireland%29">league</a> and <a href="All-Ireland%20Senior%20Football%20Championship">championship</a> career at senior level with the <a href="Fermanagh%20county%20football%20team">Fermanagh county team</a> spanned fourteen seasons from 1974 to 1988.
Born in <a href="Aghadrumsee">Aghadrumsee</a>, <a href="County%20Fermanagh">County Fermanagh</a>, McCabe first played competitive Gaelic football at <a href="St%20Eugene%27s%20College">St Eugene's College</a> in <a href="Rosslea">Rosslea</a>. He later qualified as a <a href="physical%20education">physical education</a> teacher from <a href="St%20Mary%27s%20University%20College%2C%20Belfast">St Mary's University College</a> in <a href="Belfast">Belfast</a>.
McCabe first appeared for the <a href="Aghadrumsee%20GAA">Aghadrumsee</a> club at juvenile and underage levels. He later joined the <a href="Belcoo%20O%27Rahilly%27s%20GAA">Belcoo O'Rahilly's</a> club, ending his career as a three-time <a href="Fermanagh%20Senior%20Football%20Championship">county senior championship</a> runner-up.
After lining out for Fermanagh at minor and under-21 levels, McCabe made his senior debut for the team in 1974. The highlights of his senior career include the winning of a <a href="McKenna%20Cup">McKenna Cup</a> medal in 1977 and a <a href="National%20Football%20League%20%28Ireland%29">National League Division 3</a> medal in 1981. McCabe took a break from inter-county football shortly after the latter victory, but returned for a second spell on the team from 1985 to 1988.
In retirement from playing McCabe managed Fermanagh in the early 1990s, taking them from Division 4 to Division 2. He also managed major clubs including <a href="Dromore%20St%20Dympna%27s%20GAC">Dromore</a>, <a href="Errigal%20Ciar%C3%A1n%20GAC">Errigal Ciarán</a> and <a href="Mullahoran%20GAA">Mullahoran</a>.
